comments.author: amar
comments.content:
What do you mean by the old buzi pass? Is this the track that

was used before the hingol bridge was made? I did this track

once while they were building the coastal highway. Parts of it

go through river beds, which becomes un-motorable mud after

the rains.

amar

comments.author: Abid Omar
comments.content: Yes, the track for the Old Buzi Pass goes through the river bed. It crosses the river by the remnants of a washed-away bridge. This same track is used to access the Nani Mandir. But where the jeeping gets interesting is when you leave the river bed and start climbing up through the hills. While the view from the Coastal Highway of the sea is magnificent, from the old road they are something else.

comments.author: amar
comments.content:
I think I know what you are talking about. I have done this back

in 2003. When the coastal highway was being constructed. Hence

I shared it with FWO trucks, dumpers and the trucks/buses going

to gwadar. It was dusty. And I was more worried about getting

to gwadar (still about 400kms away), rather than enjoying the

view. Believe me, it was quite an epic journey. May be some time

I will get a chance to write about it.

amar

comments.author: bergzwerg
comments.content:
—>this is pansy stuff! What about us hard core types?
—>Well, we recently came across an Austrian …

i’m the austrian. thanx for giving me an easy time after a hard trek + taking me all the way back to the main road.

i had hiked down a riverbed + hit the hingol river about 20 km north of hinglaj. walked about 120 km in 9 days. had neither guides nor camels: you want the real thing—> go get it alone.

http://bergzwerg.modblog.com/

regards + best wishes

bergzwerg

comments.author: Faisal Khan
comments.content: Is there a map of the trip? Many folks whom I have shown this website too love it and we all are wondering as if there is a map – you know – hang a right from here, hang a left from here… somethin roughly sketched out

comments.author: Ali Saeed
comments.content:
I’m planning to go there, that gonna be 100% fishing trip.

– Please reply with potential fishing points and tips. – Which baits to use, tackle etc – Which species found there

I love the info. you guys provided

Keep up the good work

Cheers

Ali Saeed

comments.author: Farooq Malik
comments.content:
Do you know where I can get the GPS Maps for the area? I want to go from Karachi to Gwadar and then on to the Iranian Border and wanted to know if I can get some GPS maps for the route. Please let me know. Thanks!

Farooq Malik

comments.author: Shahid Zaidi
comments.content:
I am impressed. Never thought there were rational folks (or Americans) who did off roading for fun, but, I am happy your artical projects you and your sport in good light.

I would be very interested in a map of the Hingol National Park and of the River.

Anybody……?

comments.author: Pervez Sadiq
comments.content: Please update the “Some Advice” section. We went to Astola Island for a bit of scuba (27 jan to 30th Jan 07) and we noticed that the Petrol pump before Liari has closed down. The best possibility is to top up at Petrol pump 13 km before the start of the coastal highway-GPS 25 33 43.74N,66 38 17.34E and then with Irani fuel at pump on the left side about 20 km on the coastal highway GPS 25 41 41.24N, 66 24 46.89E. the cost was Rs 28/l for Diesel vs 38 in karachi.

comments.author: Salim Khan
comments.content: Mr. Abdul Jabbar: a contact number would go a long way in helping the “interested” people, who would be planning to go to Hingol, to get in touch with you. Thanks

comments.author: KM Ali
comments.content:
If a map of the area is also included it would be a very useful addition to the above excellent information on Hingol.

Regards to all the members of the 4X4 club .

KM Ali from Seattle, USA

comments.author: Hafeez
comments.content:
